instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1297: What is A1297? A1297 is a model number for a 17 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Early 2009, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011 with EMC 2272, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2390, 820-2610, 820-2849, 820-2914..
definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SDA: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SDA? SMBUS_CHGR_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SCL: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SCL? SMBUS_CHGR_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.WS_KBD_ONOFF_L: What is WS_KBD_ONOFF_L? WS_KBD_ONOFF_L is a signal that comes from the keyboard that tells the SMC that the power button has been pressed.  L means whatever before the L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. This signal directly affects SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
Hi all.
I have a  macbook pro (2009/2010) that I haven't used  for a long time. Only the charger green light turns on.  I did all resets and still the same. I checked Louis Youtube video and the <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5_MCP</SIGNAL> was measuring 3mV. I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> and the rail back to normal 1.1V. I installed only the fan to check if it would run and nothing. I installed back the board and battery is disconnected. Using the power bottom, the fans still do not run.  The measurements I did so far are attached.

 I have some newbie questions:
- How to power on/off the board without the power bottom?
- In the image attached the table shows  <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_ENABLE</SIGNAL> will be 0V with out Battery. So the <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> also will be 0v and <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> will be disable and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> should be 0v like I measure even though is S5 rail?
- This voltage for the original charger (16.69V) is normal?
- Where I buy original charger and battery?


Any feedback is appreciated.

Ps: the board is in excellent condition.
Ps1: Louis you're the man. Love your Youtube Channel... Big Fan for long time.

Thanks All





[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_CONN</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]16.69V[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]8.4V[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]3.4V[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5_MCP</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]1.1V[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]0V 630ohms[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]0v[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3_REG</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]0v[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_P5VP3V3</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]8.4V[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD]???[/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]

[ATTACH type="full"]60153[/ATTACH]

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

S5 voltages are available with charger connected.
With battery (no charger), you can only get G3H voltages.

You can use <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> pads, instead of power button.
More information here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage w/ and w/o battery connected.
Magsafe light should go amber, with both charger and battery connected; unless battery is fully charged (100%).

Charger voltage looks good.
You don't need another one, for the repair.

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for pulse at <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> coil (L7220).
If present, check all other big coils.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
Thanks 2informaticos

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.4V with and also without battery connected. Magsafe light changes amber to green very quick.  Fan still do not run. I haven't used <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> or power bottom.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
The board should start with charger alone (no battery).
Test above mentioned.

Also post voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus (no battery connected).

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
Values look identical.
However, read again above linked thread and learn how to prepoerly check diode mode.
And don't write again the "V" for diode mode readings!

Check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRNTN_L</SIGNAL>, when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
Thanks for your help.

So, these are the correct values for diode test. I could find  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRNTN_L</SIGNAL>. Are you talking about PWR BTN?   I guess <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> grounds the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal for pin <SIGNAL>PWR_BUTTON</SIGNAL> on SMC.... But how about the <SIGNAL>PWR_BTN</SIGNAL>?   What is the proper way to bypass the power button? 

[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD][/TD]

[TD]Diode Mode[/TD]
[TD]Voltage[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0.514[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD]3.42V[/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[TD][RIGHT]0.515[/RIGHT][/TD]
[TD]3.42V[/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
"What is the proper way to bypass the power button?"
Read again above mentioned thread and try to understand all; take your time.
"You can use <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> pads, instead of power button."
Just a hint...

Yeah, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is not available on this board (for test).
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> instead.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message: Should the fan spin when I  connect the charger for this model right? If so, The board still has a problem.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
The fans require <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>.
I just realized now you don't have <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

Test the board with charger only on the desk.
It should start automatically, when plug in the charger.
However, nothing will happen if you don't get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
I wasn’t able to measure 3.3v. I checked at L7260 and =<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> was 0V. This happens with or without battery installed. The reset on <SIGNAL>MC_MANUAL_RST_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5001</RESISTOR>) didn’t change anything and Fan spin still off.

with this information <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v and Fan spin off I thought the board still has some issues. But for my surprise after I power on by pad <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, the fans spin.

I assembled everything and did the final test and the MacBook didn’t turn on again. So, I thought I have anything holding the board. I left everything together and did power on by pad <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> and the mac book power on ok. I think the membrane power ON/OFF switch is bad. I am not going to change the keyboard, instead I’ll try to fix this button.

I’m not sure why this MacBook fan doesn’t spin when I plug the charger or why I wasn’t able to measure <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
"I’m not sure why this MacBook fan doesn’t spin when I plug the charger"
Because has Nvidia chipset (MCP platform), not Intel.
Stop to make wrong assumprions in the future!

Check if turns on triggering <SIGNAL>WS_KBD_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
If not, change <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR>.
If yes, bad power button...

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message: It's not assumptions. I don't know all these details about about MacBook. I think I forgot to mention this is my first time working on mac. Thanks for your help. I learned a lot.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (2009) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1297</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on.
threads.message:
Pay more atention in the future.
You've had the classic <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> issue this time.
Thinking the fans should spin directly, stopped you to find bad power button (<RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> maybe?); which was the second problem of your board.
Discard basic things first, or risk to generate more damage; apart of wasting time...
